awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Evidence-based intervention software platform for autistic individuals
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of an online software platform to enhance workplace support for and increase productivity of Autistic individuals.  There is a growing body of evidence about the organizational value of hiring workers with disabilities. Many top corporations in the US embrace a social responsibility agenda, seeking to comply with federal guidelines and appeal to like-minded customers. Federal support for the inclusion of individuals with disabilities is reflected in US policies and states offer tax credits to employers who employ individuals with disabilities.  The aim of the proposed technology is to build an accessible, scalable solution, available via mobile devices (e.g., smartphone, tablet, laptop) that empowers the employee while conveying benefits to the employer.  The most important anticipated impact will be in increased opportunities for Autistic and other neurodivergent individuals, particularly those living with co-occurring behavioral health challenges, to achieve successful employment.  The use of the proposed online, accessible tools and resources may contribute to positive changes in motivation, self-efficacy, social support, and job tenure while being readily scalable.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of user-friendly online software tools and resources available via smartphone, tablet, or laptop to support Autistic employees in achieving employment success.  The proposed technology is derived from evidence-based, in-person supported employment studies and knowledge and understanding gained through years of implementation, research and multiple randomized controlled trials. In-person support is relatively expensive (e.g., training the provider, implementing logistics), not widely available, and not readily accessible in the workplace.  The initial prototype technology has been developed and validated through user-experience design and feasibility studies. It is unique in its workplace focus, research foundation, and attention to both behavioral health and neurodivergence.  The proposed tools may be effective stand-alone resources or may be used in addition to in-person support to broaden and sustain impact.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Participation in the NSF I-CORPS program provides a unique opportunity to translate research findings into accessible, effective products. The program requires attending mandatory weekly webinars and office hour sessions with instructors; preparing and presenting weekly updates on the development of our business model canvas; and customer discovery interviews with stakeholders. We interviewed 135 autistic individuals, employment specialists and service providers, autism advocates, state and community agency personnel, disability/inclusivity employment consultants, HR and Office of Diversity Directors, and Employee Resource Group representatives from large national and  international corporations, including IBM, Dell, Fidelity, Deloitte, United Healthcare, and Mass General Brigham (formerly Partners Healthcare) among others.

Through our customer discovery interviews we?ve learned some significant lessons. What makes WorkingWell unique is our focus on promoting the strengths, skills, and talents of autistic workers, focusing on co-occurring mental health needs, and supporting acceptability and accessibility in managers and work environments. In our experience, the importance of customer discovery ? of engaging directly with stakeholders and the community ? was highlighted. The interviews refined our thinking about the potential benefits of addressing challenges and barriers to employment success in the context of work, as well as ?within? the autistic employee. We discovered that employment supports for autistic individuals are ?front-end? loaded (i.e., an emphasis on identifying, recruiting, and hiring); there is a significant gap in resources and supports once the autistic individual is hired. There currently are limited opportunities for career development and promotion for autistic individuals. Available positions (e.g., in the tech world) are not necessarily reflective of autistic people?s priorities but, rather, underscore stereotypic notions about autistic individuals? ?superpowers? ? the assumption that autistic people are naturally good at technical and/or repetitive work. Our findings point to the importance of developing tools and resources for managers as well as autistic individuals, to be implemented in the workplace, to ensure that the work environment is accessible and acceptable to all.

We?ve pivoted on some of our original hypotheses. We?ve shifted our focus to private sector businesses with diversity and inclusivity initiatives as our initial customer segment; on providing software and services that encourage collaborative skill building for managers and autistic and neurodivergent employees; and on targeting improved job retention, reducing costs associated with staff turnover. Our research evidence-base and depth of experience in mental health distinguish us from potential competitors. The other important characteristic that distinguishes us is that the WorkingWell team includes autistic individuals and family members as integral team members. We are committed to a software and services model, in which we customize WorkingWell to employers/ workplace settings and tailor our tools to the employee. Ongoing services will include consultation to employers/managers and upgrades of technology and content.

In the US, more than 5.4 million adults over the age of 18 live with the challenges conveyed by autism/ND, and many with co-occurring mental health conditions. The vast majority of autistic individuals are underemployed or unemployed. Many of the existing employment initiatives rarely support sustained employment or advancing career trajectory, are not necessarily reflective of autistic people?s self-reported employment goals or work satisfaction, and do not attend to opportunities to enhance managers/supervisors? skills or optimize the context and culture of the workplace. Services for autistic adults in the US cost nearly $200 billion/year. Accessible, effective WorkingWell assistive technology, supportive of autistic/ND individuals and their managers/supervisors, has the potential to reduce significant costs to employers, families, and society, and increase the employment, independence, health and well-being of millions of autistic/ND adults.
